title: Quiz 8: Venepuncture & Urinalysis
topicName: Essential Knowledge and Skills for Healthcare Assistants
description: Test your skills in blood taking, sample handling, and urine testing.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the damage of red blood cells resulting in leakage of their contents into the serum (often caused by poor technique)?
questions.explanation: Haemolysis ruins samples, especially affecting Potassium levels.

questions.question: Which of the following can cause Haemolysis? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Leaving the tourniquet on too long
Using a needle that is too small

questions.explanation: Alcohol SHOULD dry. The others cause physical damage to cells.

questions.question: Order the steps of Venepuncture:

items.text: Clean skin and allow to dry

questions.explanation: Standard safe procedure. Tourniquet must be released before needle removal to prevent bruising.
questions.hint: Tourniquet on -> clean -> stab -> tourniquet off -> needle out.

questions.question: Why should Blood Glucose bottles usually be drawn last?

options.text: They contain an enzyme that can contaminate other tubes

questions.explanation: Cross-contamination from the fluoride/oxalate can affect other tests.

questions.question: Match the Urine Dipstick finding with its potential cause:
When performing an INR capillary test, you should NOT wipe away the first drop of blood because it contains tissue factors needed for ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: INR tests clotting. Wiping away the first drop removes tissue factors that initiate clotting.

questions.question: Which vein is usually the first choice for venepuncture in the arm?
questions.explanation: The Median Cubital is usually the most stable, anchored, and least painful.

questions.question: If you accidentally puncture an artery (bright red spurting blood), you should apply pressure for at least 5 minutes.
questions.explanation: Arteries are under high pressure. You must apply firm pressure for at least 5 mins and ensure bleeding stops.

questions.question: What does Specific Gravity (SG) on a urine strip measure?
questions.explanation: SG measures concentration. High SG = concentrated (dehydration). Low SG = dilute.

questions.question: What happens if you leave a tourniquet on for more than 1-2 minutes?

options.text: Haemoconcentration (concentration of blood components, affecting test results)

questions.explanation: Leaving the tourniquet on too long causes haemoconcentration, which can falsely elevate test results like potassium and protein.
questions.hint: Think about what happens when blood is trapped in the arm.
